topics.title: Behavioral economics and behavioral design overview
topics.summary: Kristen contrasts classical economics with behavioral economics, explaining how predictable human biases and emotions shape decisions and how behavioral design applies these insights to real-world product problems.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Flatfile (CSV importing/onboarding) and Whimsical (collaborative product/design tool).

topics.title: Irrational Labs background and client examples
topics.summary: Kristen explains what Irrational Labs does and shares examples of impact across companies (Google, TikTok, One Medical, Credit Karma), framing their work as behavior change through design and testing.

topics.title: Why “budgeting” features often don’t work
topics.summary: A FinTech case study shows that highly requested budgeting features produced no measurable behavior change; Kristen introduces behavioral diagnosis—mapping every step required—to reveal why the behavior is too hard.

topics.title: Alternatives to budgeting: defaults and rules of thumb
topics.summary: Kristen describes more effective approaches like defaults (e.g., auto-enrollment) and simple heuristics/rules-of-thumb that reduce cognitive load and make spending decisions easier to follow consistently.

topics.title: Increasing signup conversion by adding questions
topics.summary: Counterintuitively, adding lightweight multiple-choice questions can increase conversion by getting users to actively imagine benefits; Kristen shares examples (Apartment List, Trunk Club, TytoCare) and cautions against hard/open-text questions.

topics.title: Kristen’s path into behavioral economics and Google
topics.summary: Kristen recounts discovering behavioral economics via Dan Ariely, then building an embedded behavioral economics capability at Google that later scaled into a larger internal team.

topics.title: The “Three Bs” framework for behavior change
topics.summary: Kristen outlines the Three Bs—Behavior (define a specific action), Barriers (logistical and cognitive), and Benefits (especially immediate benefits)—and discusses related biases like uncertainty aversion and status quo effects.

topics.title: Ethics and incentives: the dark side of nudges
topics.summary: They discuss how behavioral tactics can be misused, with a LendingClub story illustrating how incentive structures shape outcomes; Kristen recommends aligning KPIs to customer-benefiting behaviors and longer time horizons.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Lenny promotes lennysjobs.com/talent for hiring and job-seeking in product and growth roles.

topics.title: TikTok case study: reducing misinformation sharing
topics.summary: Kristen explains how TikTok targeted the specific behavior of sharing misinformation and reduced it by 24% using friction and accuracy prompts (labels plus an “Are you sure?” interstitial) to slow users in a hot state.

topics.title: One Medical case study: onboarding to book appointments
topics.summary: To increase engagement, the team focused on booking an appointment during onboarding, reducing choice and uncertainty by asking health questions, recommending a provider, and suggesting near-term virtual times—driving a 20% lift in bookings.

topics.title: Common activation levers and “Right for Wrong” benefits
topics.summary: They discuss general patterns like making benefits concrete, reducing cognitive/logistical friction, resuming users where they left off, and using immediate motivators; Kristen expands on “Right for Wrong” incentives (e.g., donuts/lotteries) and the need to keep the end goal customer-positive.
